{{short description|Ongoing COVID-19 viral pandemic in Hong Kong}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2020}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2020}} {{Infobox pandemic | name = COVID-19 pandemic in Hong Kong | map1 = COVID-19 Outbreak Cases in Hong Kong.svg | legend1 = {{legend|#ffc0c0|0.00%-0.02% confirmed infected}}{{legend|#ee7070|0.02%-0.04% confirmed infected}}{{legend|#c80200|0.04%-0.06% confirmed infected}}{{legend|#900000|0.06%-0.08% confirmed infected}}{{legend|#510000|0.08%+ confirmed infected}} | map2 = | legend2 = | map3 = | legend3 = | disease = [[Coronavirus disease 2019|COVID-19]] | virus_strain = [[Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2|SARS-CoV-2]] | location = Hong Kong | first_case = [[Hong Kong West Kowloon railway station|West Kowloon station]], [[Kowloon]] | arrival_date = 23 January 2020
(8 months, 8 days) | origin = [[Wuhan]], [[Hubei]], China | confirmed_cases = 5,390 | active_cases = 129 | critical = 6 | recovery_cases = 5,153 | deaths = 108 | website = {{URL|www.coronavirus.gov.hk}} }} The '''COVID-19 pandemic in Hong Kong''' is part of the [[COVID-19 pandemic|worldwide pandemic]] of [[coronavirus disease 2019]] ({{nowrap|COVID-19}}) caused by [[severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2]] ({{nowrap|SARS-CoV-2}}). The virus was first confirmed to have spread to [[: Hong Kong]] on 23 January 2020. Confirmed cases were generally transferred to [[Princess Margaret Hospital (Hong Kong)|Princess Margaret Hospital]]'s Infectious Disease Centre for isolation and centralized treatment. On 5 February, after a five-day strike by front-line medical workers, the Hong Kong government closed all but three border control points – [[Hong Kong International Airport]], [[Shenzhen Bay Port|Shenzhen Bay Control Point]], and [[Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge]] Control Point remaining open. As of 10 November 2020, Hong Kong had 5,390 confirmed cases (including probable cases), with 5,153 recoveries and 108 deaths as well as 6 critical cases. Hong Kong was relatively unscathed by the first wave of the COVID-19 outbreak and had a flatter epidemic curve than most other places, which observers consider remarkable given its status as an international transport hub. Furthermore, its proximity to China and its millions of mainland visitors annually would make it vulnerable. Some experts now believe the habit of [[Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic|wearing masks]] in public since the SARS epidemic of 2003 may have helped keep its confirmed infections at 845, with four deaths, by the beginning of April.{{Cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3078437/mask-or-not-mask-who-makes-u-turn-while-us |title=To mask or not to mask: WHO makes U-turn while US, Singapore abandon pandemic advice and tell citizens to start wearing masks |date=4 April 2020 |website=[[South China Morning Post]] |access-date=13 April 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200518094122/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3078437/mask-or-not-mask-who-makes-u-turn-while-us |archive-date=18 May 2020 |url-status=live }} In a study published in April 2020 in the ''Lancet'', the authors expressed their belief that border restrictions, quarantine and isolation, social distancing, and behavioural changes such as wearing masks likely all played a part in the containment of the disease up to the end of March.{{Cite journal|url=https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanpub/article/PIIS2468-2667(20)30090-6/fulltext |title=Impact assessment of non-pharmaceutical interventions against coronavirus disease 2019 and influenza in Hong Kong: an observational study |first1=Benjamin|last1=Cowling|first2=Sheikh Taslim|last2=Ali|first3=Tiffany|last3=Ng|first4=Tim|last4=Tsang|first5=Julian|last5=Li|first6=Min Whui|last6=Fong|display-authors=etal|date=17 April 2020|access-date=26 April 2020 |journal=[[The Lancet]]|volume=5 |issue=5 |pages=e279–e288 |doi=10.1016/S2468-2667(20)30090-6 |pmid=32311320 |pmc=7164922 }} Others attributed the success to critical thinking of citizens who have become accustomed to distrusting the competence and supposed political motivations of its local government and the [[World Health Organization]]. However, Hong Kong saw an uptick in COVID-19 cases in July, with more than a hundred cases being reported several days in a row until early August. Experts attributed the rise to imported cases – sea or aircrew members, and domestic helpers classified as such cases. == Background == {{main|2019–20 Hong Kong protests|2019 Hong Kong local elections}} The outbreak of the pandemic evoked memories as the city was at the forefront of the [[2002–2004 SARS outbreak|SARS epidemic in 2003]], when over 1,700 people contracted the virus and almost 300 people died locally. The coronavirus outbreak in [[Wuhan]] took place in the backdrop of widespread and intense political conflict and civil unrest fed by anti-government sentiment, since June 2019.{{Cite news |url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-47810723 |title= Fears over Hong Kong-China extradition plans |publisher= BBC |date= 8 April 2019 |access-date= 19 June 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190614142519/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-47810723 |archive-date= 14 June 2019 |url-status= live }}{{cite news|title=Suspension of Hong Kong extradition bill is embarrassing to pro-establishment allies and could cost them at election time, camp insiders reveal|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3014674/suspension-hong-kong-extradition-bill-embarrassing-pro|first1=Kimmy|last1=Chung|first2=Tony|last2=Cheung|date=16 June 2019|newspaper=South China Morning Post|access-date=19 June 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190619021924/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3014674/suspension-hong-kong-extradition-bill-embarrassing-pro|archive-date=19 June 2019|url-status=live}} [[Carrie Lam]], the city's Chief Executive, was reported in May 2020 to have a negative approval rating of 80 percent. [[2019 Hong Kong local elections|The District Council elections]] in November, widely regarded as a proxy referendum over the protest movement's demands, saw the [[pro-democracy camp (Hong Kong)|pro-democracy camp]] achieve their biggest landslide victory in Hong Kong's history, where they took control of 17 out of 18 districts.{{cite news|title= Hong Kong citizens have their say with landslide district election result|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=25 November 2019|url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/asia/hong-kong-voters-deliver-pro-democracy-message-in-de-facto-referendum-20191125-p53dod.html}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/24/hong-kong-residents-turn-up-for-local-elections-in-record-numbers|title=Hong Kong voters deliver landslide victory for pro-democracy controversial anti-mask ban and emergency regulations|first=James|last=Promfret|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=4 October 2019|accessdate=7 October 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191004210317/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests-explainer/explainer-hong-kongs-controversial-anti-mask-ban-and-emergency-regulations-idUSKBN1WJ1FM|archive-date=4 October 2019|url-status=live}} The law would come to contradict later measures to control the spread of the virus,{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/09/hong-kong-court-upholds-face-masks-ban-despite-coronavirus|title=Hong Kong face masks ban largely upheld despite As the coronavirus crisis escalated in February and March 2020, the scale of the protests dwindled.{{cite web|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2020/02/25/not-done-yet-virus-delivers-blow-hong-kong-protests-rage-remains/|title='Not done yet': Virus delivers blow to Hong Kong protests but rage 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200301151235/https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1511792-20200301.htm|archive-date=1 March 2020|url-status=live}} Large-scale protests gave way to the coronavirus pandemic,{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/15/hong-kong-with-coronavirus-curbed-protests-may-return|title=Hong Kong: with coronavirus curbed, protests may return|first=Helen|last=Davidson|date=15 March 2020|work=The Guardian|access-date=14 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200418225551/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/15/hong-kong-with-coronavirus-curbed-protests-may-return|archive-date=18 April 2020|url-status=live}} but smaller scale protests in various districts resumed upon easing of virus restrictions. Through its Prevention and Control of Disease Ordinance, the Hong Kong government imposed a 4-person limit for public gatherings.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3077999/coronavirus-what-are-dos-donts-and-challenges|title=What are the dos, don'ts and challenges of Hong Kong's new social distancing measures?|date=2 April 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=20 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200422160944/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3077999/coronavirus-what-are-dos-donts-and-challenges|archive-date=22 April 2020|url-status=live}} Many observers believed that the coronavirus pandemic had provided cover for an increase of arrests related to the protests.{{Cite news|title=The Pandemic Is Cover for a Crackdown in Hong Kong|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/04/22/hong-kong-protests-china-coronavirus-pandemic/|date=22 April 2020|first=Antony|last=Dapiran|work=[[Foreign Policy]]|access-date=3 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200503090828/https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/04/22/hong-kong-protests-china-coronavirus-pandemic/|archive-date=3 May 2020|url-status=live}} Following the emergence of three cases of local transmission, the government extended its coronavirus social distancing measures by 14 days, to 4 June, affecting the [[31st anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests|annual commemoration of the Tiananmen Square massacre]] in Victoria Park. The government denied suggestions that the extension was aimed at interfering with the commemoration, saying the decision was made in accordance with its extension policy.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/may/19/hong-kong-blocks-tiananmen-square-vigil-with-gathering-ban|title=Hong Kong blocks Tiananmen Square vigil with gathering ban|date=19 May 2020|website=The Guardian|access-date=20 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200522072615/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/may/19/hong-kong-blocks-tiananmen-square-vigil-with-gathering-ban|archive-date=22 May 2020|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url=https://hongkongfp.com/2020/05/19/breaking-coronavirus-hong-kong-extends-social-distancing-rules-and-public-gathering-restriction/|title=Coronavirus: Hong Kong extends social distancing rules to June 4, threatening annual Tiananmen Massacre vigil|first1=Kelly|last1=Ho|first2=Jennifer|last2=Creery|date=19 May 2020|website=Hong Kong Free Press|access-date=20 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200523183033/https://hongkongfp.com/2020/05/19/breaking-coronavirus-hong-kong-extends-social-distancing-rules-and-public-gathering-restriction/|archive-date=23 May 2020|url-status=live}} ==Timeline== {{COVID-19 pandemic data/Hong Kong medical cases chart|2020-4-25=2}} ===January=== Upon learning of the outbreak, the government required disclosure by those who had been to wet markets in Wuhan. The government widened the criteria for notification on 3 January – anyone who had visited Wuhan within 14 days before the onset of any respiratory symptoms of illness would need to inform health authorities. The HK government declared a "serious response level" to the virus outbreak centred on Wuhan on 4 January, when Hong Kong announced eight suspected cases; the eight cases turned out negative for the disease from Wuhan. Medical experts in Hong Kong urged mainland authorities to be more forthcoming with Wuhan patient information that could aid epidemiological study. Although Wuhan health authorities said there was "no obvious evidence" of human-to-human transmission of the then-unidentified virus, University of Hong Kong infectious diseases expert Dr Ho Pak-leung suspected such transmission had happened among cases in Wuhan, and urged "the most stringent" precautionary measures.{{cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3044654/hong-kong-activates-serious-response-level |title=Hong Kong activates 'serious response level' for infectious diseases as Wuhan pneumonia outbreak escalates |work=South China Morning Post |date=4 January 2020 |accessdate=8 April 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200410002734/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3044654/hong-kong-activates-serious-response-level |archive-date=10 April 2020 |url-status=live }} However, press reported that border checks at the [[Hong Kong West Kowloon railway station|West Kowloon]] high-speed rail terminal were not yet operational.{{cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3044706/china-pneumonia-hong-kong-authorities-take-low |title=China pneumonia: Hong Kong authorities take low-key approach to passengers arriving in Hong Kong on Wuhan trains |work=South China Morning Post |date=22 January 2020 |accessdate=8 April 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200426212216/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3044706/china-pneumonia-hong-kong-authorities-take-low |archive-date=26 April 2020 |url-status=live }} On 8 January, Hong Kong's [[Centre for Health Protection]] (CHP) added "Severe respiratory disease associated with a novel infectious agent" to their list of [[notifiable disease]]s to expand their authority on quarantine.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3044912/hong-kong-urged-tighten-health-checks-visitors|title=Hong Kong to add mystery Wuhan pneumonia to list of notifiable infectious diseases, giving authorities power to quarantine patients|last=Siu|first=Phila|date=6 January 2020|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=8 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200114151824/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3044912/hong-kong-urged-tighten-health-checks-visitors|archive-date=14 January 2020|url-status=live}} The Hong Kong government also shortened hospital visits and made it a requirement for visitors to wear face masks. Screening was tightened at airports and train stations with connections to Wuhan.{{cite news |url= https://time.com/5759289/wuhan-pneumonia-outbreak-disease/ |title=What to Know About the Wuhan Pneumonia Oubreak|last=Leung |first=Hillary |date=6 January 2020 |website=Time |url-status=live |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20200108021836/https://time.com/5759289/wuhan-pneumonia-outbreak-disease/ |archive-date=8 January 2020 |access-date=8 January 2020}} In the first week of 2020, 30 unwell travellers from Wuhan were tested. Most had other respiratory viruses.{{cite web|url=http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2020/01/questions-still-swirl-over-chinas-unexplained-pneumonia-outbreak|title=Questions still swirl over China's unexplained pneumonia outbreak|last=Schnirring|first=Lisa|date=6 January 2020|website=CIDRAP|url-status=live|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20200106222635/http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2020/01/questions-still-swirl-over-chinas-unexplained-pneumonia-outbreak|archive-date=6 January 2020|accessdate=7 January 2020}}{{cite web|url= http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2020/01/nations-step-screening-and-await-word-chinas-pneumonia-outbreak|title=Nations step up screening and await word on China's pneumonia outbreak|last=Schnirring|first=Lisa|date=7 January 2020|website=CIDRAP|url-status=live|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20200107220738/http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2020/01/nations-step-screening-and-await-word-chinas-pneumonia-outbreak|archive-date=7 January 2020|access-date=8 January 2020}} On 22 January, a 39-year-old man from mainland China who had travelled from Shenzhen and who arrived in Hong Kong by [[Guangzhou–Shenzhen–Hong Kong Express Rail Link|high-speed rail]] developed symptoms of pneumonia. Resident in Wuhan, he had arrived in Shenzhen by highspeed rail with his family. He tested positive for the virus and was hospitalised in [[Princess Margaret Hospital (Hong Kong)|Princess Margaret Hospital]], Kowloon. The same day, a 56-year-old man from [[Ma On Shan (town)|Ma On Shan]], who had visited Wuhan in the previous week, also tested positive. These two cases were listed as "Highly Suspected Cases", they were confirmed positive the following day.{{cite news |last=Cheung |first=Elizabeth |date=22 January 2020 |title=China coronavirus: death toll almost doubles in one day as Hong Kong reports its first two cases |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3047193/china-coronavirus-first-case-confirmed-hong-kong |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |access-date= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200322000317/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3047193/china-coronavirus-first-case-confirmed-hong-kong |archive-date=22 March 2020 |url-status=live }} On 23 January, the Hong Kong government designated the Lady MacLehose Holiday Village in [[Sai Kung Town|Sai Kung]] as a quarantine centre.{{cite news |title=Visitor one of first to be quarantined over virus |url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1504443-20200123.htm |publisher=RTHK |date=23 January 2020 |access-date=22 February 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200220191957/https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1504443-20200123.htm |archive-date=20 February 2020 |url-status=live }} The Hong Kong Tourism Board cancelled the Lunar New Year Cup and a four-day Lunar New Year carnival, citing concerns over the virus outbreak.{{cite news |title=Lunar New Year carnival canceled |url=https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/4/140655/Lunar-New-Year-carnival-canceled |work=The Standard |accessdate=24 January 2020 |date=23 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200314150758/https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/4/140655/Lunar-New-Year-carnival-canceled |archive-date=14 March 2020 |url-status=live }}{{cite news |last1=Chan |first1=Kin-wa |title=Wuhan coronavirus: Lunar New Year Cup cancelled by government just hours after HKFA promotes the event |url=https://www.scmp.com/sport/hong-kong/article/3047415/wuhan-virus-lunar-new-year-cup-go-ahead-hong-kong-despite |accessdate=24 January 2020 |work=South China Morning Post |date=23 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200322061012/https://www.scmp.com/sport/hong-kong/article/3047415/wuhan-virus-lunar-new-year-cup-go-ahead-hong-kong-despite |archive-date=22 March 2020 |url-status=live }} In addition, the previous two cases of "Highly Suspected Cases" had been confirmed positive by health and government officials.{{cite web|title=Two Confirmed Imported Cases of Novel Coronavirus Infection in Hong Kong and the Revised Reporting Criteria (Letters to Doctors / Letters to Private Hospitals)|url=https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/guideline/102631.html|author=[[Centre for Health Protection]]|format=PDF|date=23 January 2020|access-date=25 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200729005337/https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/guideline/102631.html|archive-date=29 July 2020|url-status=live}} On 24 January, health authorities confirmed three more cases, all of the patients had come from Wuhan. The third case was a 62-year-old woman that had arrived to Hong Kong with her husband. They had both moved in with their daughter and son-in-law, who lived locally. Her husband, daughter and son-in-law had not developed symptoms and were both quarantined in the Lady MacLehose Holiday Village. The 4th and 5th cases were a 62-year-old woman and her husband aged 63 who had both arrived in Hong Kong on 22 January and had moved into their daughter's house. The couple attempted to escape from Prince of Wales Hospital after learning that they would have to be quarantined, but failed when the police were called.{{cite web|url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1504645-20200124.htm?spTabChangeable=0|title=Couple try to flee isolation, police drag them back|publisher=RTHK|date=24 January 2020|accessdate=17 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200729001223/https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1504645-20200124.htm?spTabChangeable=0|archive-date=29 July 2020|url-status=live}} On 25 January, the Hong Kong government declared the viral outbreak as an "emergency" – the highest warning tier.{{cite news |last1=Chan |first1=Kin-wa |title=Hong Kong declares Wuhan virus outbreak 'emergency' – the highest warning tier |url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2020/01/25/breaking-hong-kong-declares-wuhan-virus-outbreak-emergency-highest-warning-tier/ |accessdate=29 January 2020 |publisher=Hong Kong Free Press |date=25 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200128150943/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2020/01/25/breaking-hong-kong-declares-wuhan-virus-outbreak-emergency-highest-warning-tier |archive-date=28 January 2020 |url-status=live}} The city's largest amusement parks, [[Hong Kong Disneyland Resort]], [[Ocean Park Hong Kong]], and wax museum [[Madame Tussauds Hong Kong]] closed from 26 January, until further notice. Schools were declared suspended until February 17. However, Schools only reopened towards the end of May.{{cite web |last1=Chan |first1=Thomas |title=China coronavirus forces temporary closure of Hong Kong Disneyland, Ocean Park for indefinite period.|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3047672/china-coronavirus-forces-temporary-closure-hong-kong |work=South China Morning Post |accessdate=26 January 2020 |date=26 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200126031853/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3047672/china-coronavirus-forces-temporary-closure-hong-kong |archive-date=26 January 2020 |url-status=live}} On 26 January, three more cases were identified: the 6th consisted of a 47-year-old man who lived in North Point who had been working at a wet market in Wuhan for a few weeks before returning to Hong Kong; the 7th was a 68-year-old Hong Kong woman who lived in neighbouring Shenzhen and had visited Wuhan earlier that month. She was sent to North District Hospital after she presented symptoms while arriving at the Shenzhen-Hong Kong (Luowu) border on 25 January; the 8th case was the 64-year-old husband of the 3rd case in Hong Kong. He had developed a fever on the night of 25 January during quarantine, and was immediately sent to hospital to be tested for the coronavirus. A newly built housing block in [[Fanling]] in Hong Kong's [[New Territories]] that was earmarked as a quarantine facility for people who may have been exposed to Wuhan coronavirus, was fire-bombed. Dozens of residents and [[2019–20 Hong Kong protests|protesters]] opposed to the idea held rallies outside the complex.{{cite news |title=China coronavirus: proposed Hong Kong quarantine building in Fanling gets fire-bombed |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ZFMhJcruOc |accessdate=23 March 2020 |work=South China Morning Post |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200309214654/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ZFMhJcruOc&feature=youtu.be |archive-date=9 March 2020 |url-status=live }} On 28 January, Chief Executive of Hong Kong [[Carrie Lam]] announced the suspension of high-speed rail service between Hong Kong and mainland China from 30 January, a halving of all cross-border ferry services{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/live/2020/jan/28/coronavirus-first-death-in-beijing-as-us-issues-new-china-travel-warning-live-updates?page=with%3Ablock-5e2ffdce8f08e133247383ac|title=Coronavirus: Germany confirms first human transmission in Europe – live updates|last=Gayle (now)|first=Damien|date=28 January 2020|work=The Guardian|access-date=28 January 2020|last2=Rourke (earlier)|first2=Alison|issn=0261-3077|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200131044557/https://www.theguardian.com/science/live/2020/jan/28/coronavirus-first-death-in-beijing-as-us-issues-new-china-travel-warning-live-updates?page=with:block-5e2ffdce8f08e133247383ac|archive-date=31 January 2020|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url=https://hongkongfp.com/2020/01/28/wuhan-coronavirus-travel-hong-kong-china-slashed-govt-resists-pressure-close-border/|title=Wuhan coronavirus: Travel between Hong Kong and China slashed, but gov't resists pressure to close border|date=28 January 2020|website=Hong Kong Free Press|access-date=26 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200617224613/https://hongkongfp.com/2020/01/28/wuhan-coronavirus-travel-hong-kong-china-slashed-govt-resists-pressure-close-border/|archive-date=17 June 2020|url-status=live}} and flights from mainland China, cross-border bus services would also be reduced. The Hong Kong government was awaiting the for the central government's agreement to suspend issuing individual visitors permits for mainland residents to Hong Kong. All government employees (except those providing essential/emergency services) were instructed to work from home. In a press conference later that day, Lam said that the [[Man Kam To Control Point|Man Kam To]] and [[Sha Tau Kok Control Point|Sha Tau Kok]] border checkpoints would be closed.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3047907/china-coronavirus-hong-kong-government-deny-entry|title=Railway closures, no visas: Hong Kong scrambles to fight mainland virus outbreak|date=28 January 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=28 January 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200128091009/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3047907/china-coronavirus-hong-kong-government-deny-entry|archive-date=28 January 2020|url-status=live}} On 29 January, two connected cases were confirmed by health officials. The 9th and 10th cases consisted of a couple from Wuhan in their 70s who had arrived in Hong Kong on board Cathay Dragon KA853 on 22 January, and checked into a hotel in West Kowloon on the same day. They had visited multiple restaurants at the hotel, the Elements mall, the Ritz Carlton. During their visit to the Four Seasons Hotel on 28 January, the staff who noticed that the couple had a persistent cough and appeared unwell called an ambulance, and both were transferred to Hospital, where they tested positive for coronavirus. The [[Leisure and Cultural Services Department]] (LCSD) announced that all facilities overseen by the department including all public museums, public libraries and sports centres and venues would be closed until further notice as a precaution.{{cite web|url=https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/clpss/en/webApp/NewsDetails.do?id=14683|title=Temporary closure of LCSD facilities from tomorrow|date=28 January 2020|website=[[Leisure and Cultural Services Department]] |access-date=29 January 2020}} On 14 February, the LCSD announced that the closure of its facilities would be extended until 2 March 2020.{{cite web|url=https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/clpss/en/webApp/NewsDetails.do?id=14703|title=Latest arrangements on LCSD public services|date=14 February 2020|website=[[Leisure and Cultural Services Department]]|access-date=14 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200220235522/https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/clpss/en/webApp/NewsDetails.do?id=14703|archive-date=20 February 2020|url-status=live}} On 28 April, [[Hong Kong Public Libraries]] announced a partial reopening of some of its locations from 6 May.{{cite web|url=https://www.hkpl.gov.hk/en/library-notices/re-openingofvenues_s3bmvbuf4uemg9h4l0kdh9vhut.html|title=Latest arrangements on services of Hong Kong Public Libraries|date=28 April 2020|website=[[Hong Kong Public Libraries]]|access-date=3 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200503054609/https://www.hkpl.gov.hk/en/library-notices/re-openingofvenues_s3bmvbuf4uemg9h4l0kdh9vhut.html|archive-date=3 May 2020|url-status=dead}} On 30 January, two new cases of coronavirus were confirmed. The 11th case was a 39-year-old woman who lived and worked in Hong Kong – the daughter of the 9th and 10th (couple from Wuhan) cases. She had previously also stayed with them at the W Hotel in West Kowloon, and also visited the Hong Kong with them. She developed symptoms on 28 January after sending her parents to hospital. She was the first case of local transmission in Hong Kong. The 12th patient was a 75-year-old man who lived in Tsing Yi who had visited Guangdong province in China from late December till early January, and Macau for several days in mid-January. He developed coughing symptoms on 22 January and was hospitalised in a regular hospital room at the Queen Margaret Hospital. Not having declared his travel history, he was initially not tested for the coronavirus. On 30 January, his conditions worsened and he tested positive for the coronavirus.{{cite news|author=|title=Hong Kong confirms two more coronavirus cases|url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1505760-20200131.htm|work=rthk|date=31 January 2020|access-date=18 September 2020}}{{cite news|vauthors=Cheung E, Wong B|title=Hong Kong confirms 12th case of deadly coronavirus|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3048289/china-coronavirus-another-patient-tests-positive|work=South China Morning Post|date=30 January 2020|access-date=18 September 2020}} On 31 January, the 13th case of COVID-19 was confirmed – a 39-year-old Hong Kong man with diabetes who lived in Whampoa, Kowloon. He had come back from Wuhan in the previous week, developed muscle pain on 29 January and a cough and fever on 31 January. After he was confirmed to have the coronavirus, his family were transferred to a quarantine camp.{{cite news|author=|title=CHP confirms 13th case of Wuhan virus in Hong Kong|url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1505979-20200201.htm|work=rthk|date=1 February 2020|access-date=18 September 2020}} ===February=== On 4 February, the CHP reported Hong Kong's first death, the world's second outside mainland China, of a 39-year-old patient, the 13th case.{{cite web |title=Hong Kong reports first death from coronavirus |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/hong-kong-reports-first-death-from-coronavirus |website=The Straits Times |accessdate=4 February 2020 |date=4 February 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200204025501/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/hong-kong-reports-first-death-from-coronavirus |archive-date=4 February 2020 |url-status=live}} Three cases were confirmed on 5 February,{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049141/coronavirus-three-new-cases-hong-kong-include|title=Coronavirus: three new cases in Hong Kong include wife and daughter of man who already has disease|last1=Cheung|first1=Elizabeth|date=5 February 2020|website=South China Morning Post|accessdate=5 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200205073511/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049141/coronavirus-three-new-cases-hong-kong-include|archive-date=5 February 2020|url-status=live}} three on 6 February,{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049333/one-more-confirmed-coronavirus-case-hong-kong-two|title=New confirmed coronavirus case in Hong Kong, as two more test positive|last1=Lum|first1=Alvin|last2=Cheung|first2=Elizabeth|date=6 February 2020|website=South China Morning Post|accessdate=6 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200206083525/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049333/one-more-confirmed-coronavirus-case-hong-kong-two|archive-date=6 February 2020|url-status=live}} and another two on 7 February.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-51419015|title=Hong Kong imposes new quarantine rules over virus|date=7 February 2020|publisher=BBC|access-date=8 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200208002752/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-51419015|archive-date=8 February 2020|url-status=live}} On 9 February, Hong Kong confirmed three more cases with two from the same family, bringing the total number to 29.{{cite web|url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1507567-20200209.htm|title=Three more virus cases in HK, two in same family|date=9 February 2020|website=RTHK|access-date=9 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200210180752/https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1507567-20200209.htm|archive-date=10 February 2020|url-status=live}} It was also announced on the same day that the passengers and crew of the World Dream cruise ship were allowed to leave after a check revealed that they were negative for the coronavirus and had no history of being in close contact with eight disembarked passengers who were tested positive for the virus.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049714/coronavirus-3600-passengers-and-crew-members|title=3,600 passengers, crew quarantined on cruise ship finally leave|date=9 February 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=15 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200216011833/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049714/coronavirus-3600-passengers-and-crew-members|archive-date=16 February 2020|url-status=live}} On 19 February, a 70-year-old man with pre-existing illnesses became the second person to die of COVID-19 in Hong Kong.{{cite web|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2020/02/19/breaking-70-year-old-dies-bringing-hong-kong-coronavirus-death-toll-two|title=Coronavirus: 70-year-old dies, bringing Hong Kong toll to two|date=19 February 2020|website=Hong Kong Free Press|access-date=26 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200226181952/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2020/02/19/breaking-70-year-old-dies-bringing-hong-kong-coronavirus-death-toll-two|archive-date=26 February 2020|url-status=live}} On 24 February, seven new cases were identified that included two evacuees from [[COVID-19 pandemic on Diamond Princess|''Diamond Princess'']], a cruise ship quarantined in Japan, bringing the total number of cases to 81.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3052064/coronavirus-two-more-test-positive-hong-kong|title=Coronavirus: two more Hong Kong evacuees from Diamond Princess cruise ship confirmed with infection, bringing city's total to 81|date=24 February 2020|website=South China Morning Post |access-date=25 February 2020}} ===March=== [[File:Street in Hong Kong during the COVID-19 pandemic.jpg|thumb|Street in Hong Kong during the COVID-19 pandemic]] As of 2 March, Hong Kong had reached 100 confirmed cases. Two new cases were confirmed that day which include a brother of a COVID-19 patient and a woman from the Diamond Princess cruise ship. An 88-year-old man living at a care home in [[Shau Kei Wan]] had tested "weak positive" for the virus the same day, further tests would be done to test whether he was infected.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3064652/coronavirus-hong-kong-marks-first-day-without|title=Hong Kong reaches 100 coronavirus cases as two more infections confirmed|date=2 March 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=2 March 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200302114018/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3064652/coronavirus-hong-kong-marks-first-day-without|archive-date=2 March 2020|url-status=live}} On 20 March, Hong Kong recorded 48 new coronavirus infections, the biggest daily tally since testing began, bringing the total to 256 confirmed cases. Of these cases, 36 had a travel history. [[Gabriel Leung]], member of an expert panel on the viral outbreak, warned the public about letting down their vigilance prematurely as Hong Kong was at the "highest risk" since the start of the pandemic.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3076113/coronavirus-highest-risk-yet-new-covid-19|title=Hong Kong reaches 256 coronavirus cases as 48 more infections confirmed|date=20 March 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=2 March 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200320081020/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3076113/coronavirus-highest-risk-yet-new-covid-19|archive-date=20 March 2020|url-status=live}} An article published on 25 March by the office of Chief Executive [[Carrie Lam]] warned that an increase in confirmed cases would "inevitably" occur as long as Hong Kong citizens continued to return from abroad.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3076932/coronavirus-hong-kong-records-24-new-cases-mostly|title=Tougher measures against coronavirus may come this week as Hong Kong fights to contain local clusters and imported cases |date=25 March 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=1 May 2020}} On 22 March, the [[Hong Kong University of Science and Technology]] published an article on [[Multilevel Antimicrobial Polymer]] (MAP-1), a surface coating spray that inactivates viruses, bacteria and [[spore]]s and that was successfully used in the combat of COVID-19 in public places like schools, shopping malls and school buses.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ust.hk/news/research-and-innovation/hkust-develops-new-smart-anti-microbial-coating-fight-against-covid-19|title=HKUST Develops New Smart Anti-Microbial Coating in the Fight Against COVID-19 | The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology|date=10 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200510053302/https://www.ust.hk/news/research-and-innovation/hkust-develops-new-smart-anti-microbial-coating-fight-against-covid-19|archive-date=10 May 2020}} On 25 March, Hong Kong closed its border to all incoming nonresidents arriving from overseas. Transiting through Hong Kong was no longer allowed either. All returning residents, regardless of point of departure, were subject to the Compulsory Quarantine Order, which required all to stay at a reported quarantine premise (either home or hotel) for 14 days. Tracking devices were employed to enforce the order. All returning residents from the United States, the UK, and continental Europe were required to go through enhanced screening and submit saliva sample for COVID-19 testing.{{cite web|url=https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202003/24/P2020032400050.htm|title=Government announces enhancements to anti-epidemic measures in four aspects|date=24 March 2020|website=The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region|access-date=27 March 2020}} On 27 March, Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam banned indoor and outdoor public gatherings of more than four people, for 14 days starting from 29 March. Other regulations enacted, which took effect at the same time, included requiring restaurants to operate at half their capacity and to set tables at least 1.5 meters apart.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-hongkong/hong-kong-bans-public-gatherings-of-more-than-four-people-idUSKBN21E1MW|title=Hong Kong bans public gatherings of more than four people |agency=Reuters|date=27 April 2020|access-date=2 May 2020}} ===April=== On 1 April, the Hong Kong government announced the temporary closure of karaoke lounges, nightclubs and [[mah-jong]] premises. Confusion over the government's listing of venues to be temporarily closed led the public to believe that other venues such as beauty parlors, massage parlors and clubhouses would have to be closed as well. However the government clarified that such establishments would be allowed to remain open subject to businesses providing hand sanitiser to customers, as well as requiring customers to wear a mask and have their temperature taken while inside the business venue.{{cite web|url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1518212-20200401.htm?|title=Karaokes, clubs, mahjong parlours ordered to close|publisher=RTHK|access-date=1 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200401214841/https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1518212-20200401.htm|archive-date=1 April 2020|url-status=live}} On 3 April at 18:00, all pubs and bars across the territory were ordered to close for 14 days.{{cite web|url=https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2020/04/20200402/20200402_195740_071.html|title=Restrictions on bars gazetted – Govt News|publisher=Government of Hong Kong|access-date=5 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200406150809/https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2020/04/20200402/20200402_195740_071.html|archive-date=6 April 2020|url-status=live}} At a press briefing on 21 April, Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced that the social distancing rules, which already been extended previously,{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/hong-kong-to-extend-coronavirus-related-restrictions-by-14-days|title=Hong Kong to extend coronavirus-related restrictions by 14 days|work=[[The Straits Times]]|date=21 April 2020|access-date=3 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200429163542/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/hong-kong-to-extend-coronavirus-related-restrictions-by-14-days|archive-date=29 April 2020|url-status=live}} would be extended beyond 23 April by 14 days.{{cite news|url=https://hongkongfp.com/2020/04/21/breaking-hong-kong-social-distancing-rules-extended-for-14-days/|title=Coronavirus: Hong Kong social distancing rules extended for 14 days|first=Jennifer|last=Creery|publisher=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=21 April 2020|access-date=3 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200429004755/https://hongkongfp.com/2020/04/21/breaking-hong-kong-social-distancing-rules-extended-for-14-days/|archive-date=29 April 2020|url-status=live}} Shortly after the press briefing, the [[Food and Health Bureau]] said that the cap on the number of customers at 50 per cent capacity would be relaxed. In late April, researchers at the [[Hong Kong University of Science and Technology]] said that a newly developed antiviral coating may provide up to 90 days of "significant" protection against COVID-19. The disinfectant is encapsulated in heat-sensitive polymers and released when there is human contact with a surface such as a handrail or elevator button.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-hongkong-coating/hk-scientists-say-new-antiviral-coating-can-protect-surfaces-for-90-days-idUSKCN2290S5|title=HK scientists say new antiviral coating can protect surfaces for 90 days|agency=Reuters|access-date=30 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200429174002/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-hongkong-coating/hk-scientists-say-new-antiviral-coating-can-protect-surfaces-for-90-days-idUSKCN2290S5|archive-date=29 April 2020|url-status=live}} ===May=== On 1 May, no major Labour Day demonstrations were authorised as the gathering limit of four persons was upheld. Police handed out 18 penalty tickets for breach of social-distancing rules at street booths and at a singalong event in a mall.{{cite web|title=Hong Kong protests: police issued 18 penalty tickets for breach of social-distancing rules over Labour Day demonstrations |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3082578/hong-kong-protests-police-issued-18-penalty-tickets|first=Chris|last=Lau|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=2 May 2020|access-date=3 May 2020}} On 5 May, Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced that the cap on public gatherings would be raised from four to eight people, and that a number of businesses including beauty salons and gyms would be allowed to reopen subject to precautions. The number of people allowed to use a single table in restaurants and catering facilities was likewise increased from four to eight. Schools will resume classes in stages from 27 May, starting with secondary schools and moving progressively to younger ages.{{cite web|title=Coronavirus: Hong Kong to relax business restrictions with gathering limit upped to 8 people|url=https://hongkongfp.com/2020/05/05/breaking-coronavirus-hong-kong-relaxes-business-restrictions-as-gathering-limit-upped-to-8-people/|first1=Jennifer|last1=Creery|first2=Rachel|last2=Wong|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=5 May 2020|access-date=12 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200518153413/https://hongkongfp.com/2020/05/05/breaking-coronavirus-hong-kong-relaxes-business-restrictions-as-gathering-limit-upped-to-8-people/|archive-date=18 May 2020|url-status=live}} By 30 May, a total of sixteen passengers arriving in Hong Kong from Pakistan on Qatar Airways flight QR818 on 28 May had tested positive.{{cite web|title=Covid cases rise among passengers of Thursday flight|url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1529308-20200530.htm|publisher=[[RTHK]]|date=30 May 2020|access-date=31 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200728235532/https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1529308-20200530.htm|archive-date=28 July 2020|url-status=live}}{{cite web|title=Coronavirus: Hong Kong woman tests preliminary positive for Covid-19 in possible break of 16-day streak of no local infections|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3086810/coronavirus-hong-kong-records-least-three-new|first1=Danny|last1=Lee|first2=Ho-him|last2=Chan|first3=Lilian|last3=Cheng|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=30 May 2020|access-date=31 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200531011825/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3086810/coronavirus-hong-kong-records-least-three-new|archive-date=31 May 2020|url-status=live}} Also on 30 May, a 34-year-old woman with no recent travel history tested preliminary positive. ===June=== The Hong Kong Government extended the social distancing measures for two more weeks, until 18 June, after six people were confirmed infected, including a female employee at Kerry Logistics warehouse in Kwai Chung, her husband, two colleagues and the paramedic.{{cite web|title=Coronavirus: Hong Kong extends social-distancing curbs including gathering ban, compulsory quarantine as four new cluster cases raise ‘super spreader’ fears|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3087082/coronavirus-four-new-cases-same-housing-estate|website=South China Morning Post|date=2 June 2020|access-date=3 June 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200603154830/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3087082/coronavirus-four-new-cases-same-housing-estate|archive-date=3 June 2020|url-status=live}} The Hong Kong Government later decided to evacuate some residents in Luk Chuen House at [[Lek Yuen Estate]] in [[Sha Tin]], where the confirmed cases were found.{{cite web|title=Coronavirus: Hong Kong public housing estate evacuated after cluster of Covid-19 infections found|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3087526/coronavirus-new-cluster-infection-expands-elderly|date=4 June 2020|access-date=7 June 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200607172749/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3087526/coronavirus-new-cluster-infection-expands-elderly|archive-date=7 June 2020|url-status=live}} On 8 June, the government announced that [[Ocean Park, Hong Kong|Ocean Park]] is set to reopen on 13 June while Hong Kong Disneyland will reopen "soon". Both theme parks suffered from financial difficulties during the pandemic. Trade fairs and conventions, which were suspended since the beginning of the year, will be hosted again in Hong Kong starting with the [[Hong Kong Book Fair]] on 15 and 21 July.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3087984/ocean-park-disneyland-reopen-soon-commerce|title=Ocean Park, Disneyland to reopen soon as commerce secretary pledges reboot for Hong Kong’s economy on back of tourism, trade|first=Denise|last=Tsang|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=8 June 2020|accessdate=9 June 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200609031401/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3087984/ocean-park-disneyland-reopen-soon-commerce|archive-date=9 June 2020|url-status=live}} === July === There was an increase in confirmed COVID-19 cases in July, following a 21-day period of no confirmed local cases. A cook in a restaurant confirmed positive on 5 July;{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3093978/hong-kong-third-wave-how-did-citys-scariest-surge|title=How did Hong Kong’s third wave of Covid-19 infections start?|date=21 July 2020|first1=Victor|last1=Ting|first2=Elizabeth|last2=Cheung|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=28 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200728062503/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3093978/hong-kong-third-wave-how-did-citys-scariest-surge|archive-date=28 July 2020|url-status=live}} a person from Ping Shek Estate and a nurse from a nearby clinic were diagnosed with the coronavirus the following day. However, on 7 July 16 people were locally infected from multiple districts, the highest local increase in cases since the start of the pandemic in Hong Kong. On 9 July 34 locally infected cases were reported, with new social gathering restrictions enforced from the following midnight. However, with the addition of 41 locally infected cases reported on 13 July the Hong Kong government further reduced the limit on public gatherings from 50 to 4.{{Cite web|url=https://hd.stheadline.com/news/realtime/hk/1818631/%E5%8D%B3%E6%99%82-%E6%B8%AF%E8%81%9E-%E6%9E%97%E9%84%AD-%E9%A3%9F%E8%82%866%E9%BB%9E%E5%BE%8C%E4%B8%8D%E5%87%86%E5%A0%82%E9%A3%9F-%E4%B9%98%E6%90%AD%E5%85%AC%E5%85%B1%E4%BA%A4%E9%80%9A%E9%A0%88%E6%88%B4%E5%8F%A3%E7%BD%A9|title=林鄭:食肆6點後不准堂食 乘搭公共交通須戴口罩|work=頭條日報|access-date=13 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200714205120/https://hd.stheadline.com/news/realtime/hk/1818631/%E5%8D%B3%E6%99%82-%E6%B8%AF%E8%81%9E-%E6%9E%97%E9%84%AD-%E9%A3%9F%E8%82%866%E9%BB%9E%E5%BE%8C%E4%B8%8D%E5%87%86%E5%A0%82%E9%A3%9F-%E4%B9%98%E6%90%AD%E5%85%AC%E5%85%B1%E4%BA%A4%E9%80%9A%E9%A0%88%E6%88%B4%E5%8F%A3%E7%BD%A9|archive-date=14 July 2020|url-status=live}} A notable cluster of 44 patients linked to a home for the elderly emerged; Tsz Wan Shan district also recorded more than 150 cases. A total of 108 new cases were confirmed on 19 July – the highest since March: 83 cases were local in origin, while 25 were imported.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3093795/hong-kong-third-wave-more-100-confirmed-and|title=Hong Kong steps up Covid-19 fight with ‘no signs situation is under control’|date=19 July 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=21 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200721142430/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3093795/hong-kong-third-wave-more-100-confirmed-and|archive-date=21 July 2020|url-status=live}} The majority of the locally transmitted cases cannot be traced back to a single group gathering or event.{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/hong-kong-returns-social-distancing-critical-3rd-wave/story?id=71792082|title=Hong Kong returns to social distancing as ‘critical’ 3rd wave hits city|website=ABC News|access-date=21 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200721125535/https://abcnews.go.com/International/hong-kong-returns-social-distancing-critical-3rd-wave/story?id=71792082|archive-date=21 July 2020|url-status=live}} That day, the government announced a raft of measures hoping to slow the spread: civil servants are to work from home and only emergency and essential public services will remain open; eat-in restaurants will be banned from 6pm to 5am, and mask-wearing in indoor public places is henceforth mandatory. The growth in the number of patients during the week to 25 July put pressure on isolation facilities in public hospitals, which were reported to be running close to maximum capacity. Carrie Lam announced that she had requested help from mainland health authorities, and that testing capacity would be increased with their help; areas of AsiaWorld-Expo would be upgraded to serve as a “mobile cabin hospital”.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3094681/hong-kong-third-wave-elderly-man-becomes-citys|title=Officials ‘very worried’ as Hong Kong tops daily record with 133 Covid-19 cases|first1=Elizabeth|last1=Cheung|first2=Kanis|last2=Leung|first3=Ho-him|last3=Chan|date=25 July 2020|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=28 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200728092933/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3094681/hong-kong-third-wave-elderly-man-becomes-citys|archive-date=28 July 2020|url-status=live}} While pro-Beijing political groups have requested medical personnel from officials from the liaison office, members of the medical profession expressed reservations that those sent are not licensed to practise medicine locally; furthermore there were concerns that cooperation would not be straightforward because of language, political and cultural issues. The liaison office criticised their "arrogance and prejudice" in resisting the offer of support, and effectively putting political consideration above people's safety.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3094800/hong-kong-third-wave-beijings-liaison-office-blasts-critics|title=Beijing agencies attack critics of Covid-19 help for Hong Kong|first1=Tony|last1=Cheung|first2=Victor|last2=Ting|date=27 July 2020|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=28 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200727180054/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3094800/hong-kong-third-wave-beijings-liaison-office-blasts-critics|archive-date=27 July 2020|url-status=live}} On 28 July, [[Secretary for Food and Health]] [[Sophia Chan]] admitted that there was "empirial evidence" that quarantine exemption policies for over 30 groups of inbound travellers – including cross-boundary goods vehicle drivers, aircraft crew members, government officials on duty, and numerous company executives – had contributed to the recent increase in coronavirus cases.{{Cite web|url=https://hongkongfp.com/2020/07/28/covid-19-surge-hong-kong-admits-quarantine-exemptions-may-be-to-blame-as-city-sees-106-new-infections/|title=Covid-19 surge: Hong Kong admits quarantine exemptions may be to blame, as city sees 106 new infections|first=Kelly|last=Ho|date=28 July 2020|website=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|access-date=29 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200729045145/https://hongkongfp.com/2020/07/28/covid-19-surge-hong-kong-admits-quarantine-exemptions-may-be-to-blame-as-city-sees-106-new-infections/|archive-date=29 July 2020|url-status=live}} Experts had been pointing to such loopholes as a likely cause already a week earlier, mentioning in addition returning domestic workers. The 118 new cases announced that day heralded the eighth consecutive day of three-digit infections per day. Social-distancing rules were further toughened by limiting public gatherings to two people; banning eating-in at restaurants; and making the wearing of face masks compulsory in all public places.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3095115/hong-kong-third-wave-elderly-woman-latest-covid|title=Hong Kong third wave: Covid-19 total exceeds 3,000 with 118 new infections, one related death as new hotline service launched|date=29 July 2020|first1=Elizabeth|last1=Cheung|first2=Victor|last2=Ting|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=29 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200729085537/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3095115/hong-kong-third-wave-elderly-woman-latest-covid|archive-date=29 July 2020|url-status=live}} However, the ban on eating-in was highly unpopular with the public amid viral images of workers eating their lunchboxes on roadsides in the heat and rain. It ended in a government U-turn after 48 hours.{{Cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3095283/hong-kong-third-wave-government-changes-mind |title=Hong Kong third wave: officials scrap coronavirus-related ban on eating in restaurants after just 24 hours |access-date=30 July 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200730141345/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3095283/hong-kong-third-wave-government-changes-mind |archive-date=30 July 2020 |url-status=live }} === August === A team of mainland health officials charged with carrying out COVID-19 testing arrived in Hong Kong at the beginning of the month, ostensibly to step up the testing capacity.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-53633446|title=China sends Covid-19 medical team to Hong Kong|date=3 August 2020|publisher=BBC}} Although details have not yet been finalised by the time of the team's arrival, the free voluntary universal testing programme aims to test all residents within two weeks, to quickly detect silent transmissions in light of the rapid rise in cases, according to the government.{{Cite web|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/hong-kong-to-offer-free-virus-testing-to-whole-city-says-hk01|title=Hong Kong to offer free Covid-19 tests to all residents|date=7 August 2020|website=The Straits Times}} On 17 August, Hong Kong banned Air India from flying to the city for two weeks over imported COVID-19 cases. The Hong Kong Government invoked emergency public health powers after linking 11 imported coronavirus infections to a 14 August flight from New Delhi. "The fact 11 passengers tested positive on the same flight shows the lab tests back in India are not very reliable," a government source said. "The airline has to do deep cleaning [on its planes] and make sure it won’t happen again on future flights before they can be resumed."https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3097732/hong-kong-revokes-permission-air-india-charter?utm_source=Facebook === September === The government announced further relaxation of social distancing measures. Among them, the dine-in time of restaurants was extended to midnight, and bars, pubs and some listed premises that were not open earlier could be reopened. The relevant regulations will take effect on Friday for a period of seven days. The Secretary for Food and Health, Chen Zhaoshi, said at a press conference today that the epidemic has continued to ease and gradually stabilized. In addition, the universal community testing program has identified many invisible patients in the community, which will help further stabilize the epidemic. Therefore, the government is confident to continue to relax gradually. Social distancing measures. The latest ban on dining in restaurants is from 0:00 to 4:59 a.m., the number of customers in catering premises shall not exceed half the number of seats in the premises and the maximum four people sitting at the same table shall remain unchanged. Bars, pubs and catering premises selling or supplying alcohol can be reopened, but the number of customers shall not exceed half the number of seats on the premises, and no more than two persons sitting at the same table. Some of the listed premises that involved a higher risk of infection and failed to open in the first three stages of relaxation measures, namely bathrooms, public entertainment venues including theme parks and exhibition venues, party rooms, nightclubs or nightclubs, karaoke venues and The swimming pool can also be reopened, but it must comply with relevant regulations and restrictions, and strictly implement infection control measures. The government has also relaxed the restrictions that currently apply to certain listed premises, including restrictions on wearing masks and group arrangements in fitness centers and sports premises. As for the number of people gathered in groups in public places, the maximum number of people is four, and the requirement to wear masks in public transport and public places also continues to take effect. Chen Zhaoshi pointed out that the virus will not disappear before effective vaccines appear. Many experts also predict that the fourth wave of epidemics will break out in winter. After the government summarizes the experience of responding to the third wave of epidemics and the actual local situation, it is expected that social interaction will not be greatly relaxed in the future. Distance measures to the extent of June. She also emphasized that the relaxation of social distancing measures is staged and conditional; if the next wave of epidemic occurs, the government will adopt a more targeted model to tighten social distancing measures, so as to reduce the risk of virus transmission while maintaining a certain level of society. Normal activities. In addition, Chen Zhaoshi said that the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department has sent additional staff to inspect food premises to ensure that operators and practitioners comply with the requirements under the relevant regulations. The department will also strengthen law enforcement with other departments and take actions against illegal food premises. The FEHD inspected 3,493 food and beverage premises from 11 to 13 this month, and prosecuted 53 persons in charge of the premises, mainly involving irregular distance between tables, more than half of the number of customers on the premises, and customers not wearing them during non-dining periods Masks. == Shortages == [[File:20200205HK mask queues.jpg|thumb|Aerial view in Kowloon Bay, 5 February 2020, showing long queues to buy masks going around a block]] Since the outbreak, the availability of a significant number of products including toilet paper, face masks and disinfectant products (such as alcohol and bleach) came under pressure across the city.{{cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3048097/long-queues-outlets-across-hong-kong-selling |title=Hundreds queue for masks amid virus crisis, with some in line at 7 am |date=29 January 2020 |website=South China Morning Post |access-date=31 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200130183327/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3048097/long-queues-outlets-across-hong-kong-selling |first1=Ho-him|last1=Chan|first2=Lok-kei|last2=Sum|archive-date=30 January 2020 |url-status=live}} An ongoing period of panic buying has also caused many stores to be cleared of non-medical products such as bottled water, vegetables, and rice.{{cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3048121/china-coronavirus-shelves-cleared-essentials-spread-sparks |title=Shelves cleared as coronavirus spread sparks Hong Kong panic buying |first1=Kimmy|last1=Chung|first2=Brian|last2=Wong|first3=Zoe|last3=Low|date=29 January 2020 |website=[[South China Morning Post]] |access-date=31 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200130185856/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3048121/china-coronavirus-shelves-cleared-essentials-spread-sparks |archive-date=30 January 2020 |url-status=live}} On the professional level, the Hospital Authority reported at the end of January that stock of surgical masks for public hospitals had fallen below three-months' supply, but said it hoped to secure replenishment lasting until June. Chief Executive Carrie Lam said she had written to the State Council hoping to obtain supplies from mainland China. The [[Government of Hong Kong]] had its imports of face masks cancelled as global face mask stockpiles declined.{{cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3048332/china-coronavirus-hongkongers-online-orders-masks |title=Coronavirus: Hongkongers’ online orders for masks cancelled as overseas suppliers report shortages |date=31 January 2020 |website=[[South China Morning Post]] |access-date=31 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200131031715/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3048332/china-coronavirus-hongkongers-online-orders-masks |first=Lok-kei|last=Sum|archive-date=31 January 2020 |url-status=live}} As 80 per cent of surgical masks sold in Hong Kong were mainland-sourced, the considerable internal demand for masks rendered Hong Kong a lower priority. At the retail level, masks and hand sanitiser were in short supply by the end of January. Desperate citizens took to chasing supplies across town, rushing to any store where they may be available, and many pharmacies had long queues forming outside; some would queue overnight despite advice from stores. Unsuccessful customers took out their frustrations on store staff, and disputes were widely reported; police were called on one occasion by pharmacy staff in [[Tin Shui Wai]]. Most stores had limited supplies, and customers would often face rationing.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3048176/china-coronavirus-tensions-high-thousands-queue|first=Lok-kei|last1=Sum|first2=Zoe|last2=Low|title=Thousands queue for masks in Hong Kong, fearing spread of virus|date=30 January 2020|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=12 April 2020|archive-url=https://archive.today/20200406110408/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3048176/china-coronavirus-tensions-high-thousands-queue|archive-date=6 April 2020|url-status=live}} In addition to toilet paper, flour became oversold as citizens took up home baking.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3079495/after-long-lines-toilet-paper-and-masks-another|title=Flour latest item to grow scarce during coronavirus outbreak|date=11 April 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=12 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200412203002/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3079495/after-long-lines-toilet-paper-and-masks-another|archive-date=12 April 2020|url-status=live}} Amidst shortages due to hoarding, the Mong Kok branch of [[Wellcome]] supermarket was robbed by armed gangs who made off with 50 packets (600 rolls) of toilet paper.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3050907/armed-gang-steals-hk1000-toilet-paper-coronavirus|title=Two arrested after armed gang makes run for toilet rolls in HK$1,600 heist as coronavirus panic shows no signs of easing|first=Ho-him|last=Chan|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=17 February 2020|accessdate=8 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200407150905/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3050907/armed-gang-steals-hk1000-toilet-paper-coronavirus|archive-date=7 April 2020|url-status=live}} In early February, after CSI masks appeared in the local marketplace, the government was called to account for the supplies of masks manufactured by inmates in local prisons under the aegis of the Correctional Services Industries. In 2019, masks were produced at a rate of 4 million in each quarter by the Correctional Services Department, and were distributed among various government departments. Media reported that the stocks within different departments were freely available to staff before the lunar new year. Due to the onset of the epidemic, they suddenly became a precious commodity in Hong Kong, and the abuse was highlighted.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049900/hong-kongs-public-investigating-authorities-under|title=Hong Kong under pressure to probe misuse of masks meant for civil servants|first=Lilian|last=Cheng|date=11 February 2020|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=28 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200402143457/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049900/hong-kongs-public-investigating-authorities-under|archive-date=2 April 2020|url-status=live}} Following an admission that the city had failed to procure adequate supplies of [[Personal Protective Equipment|PPE]], the government announced support for local private mask production by subsidising each production line with grants, help in identifying suitable premises, as well as placing orders to sustain their operations. An increase in mask production by Correctional Services Industries from 1.8 million to 2.5 million units a month is planned.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3050813/coronavirus-mask-production-lines-could-be|title=Coronavirus: mask production lines could be running within weeks, though Hong Kong firms seek aid beyond cash subsidies|first=Kanis|last=Leung|date=15 February 2020|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=28 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200726060059/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3050813/coronavirus-mask-production-lines-could-be|archive-date=26 July 2020|url-status=live}} The government announced that its procurement had fallen victim to a scam involving 6 million counterfeit masks bearing the Medicom trademark valued at HK$15 million ($1.9 million).{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3091616/coronavirus-more-6-million-masks-procured-hong-kong|title=Coronavirus: more than 6 million masks procured by Hong Kong government found to be fake|first=Kang-chung|last=Ng|date=3 July 2020|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=28 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200703102512/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3091616/coronavirus-more-6-million-masks-procured-hong-kong|archive-date=3 July 2020|url-status=live}} ==Impact== In view of the coronavirus outbreak, the [[Education Bureau]] closed all kindergartens, primary schools, secondary schools, and special schools until 20 April.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3075521/coronavirus-little-if-any-possibility-hong-kong-schools|title=Coronavirus: 'little, if any, possibility' Hong Kong schools resume fully on April 20, Lam says|website=South China Morning Post|first1=Tony|last1=Cheung|first2=Natalie|last2=Wong|first3=Ho-him|last3=Chan|access-date=23 March 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200322195355/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3075521/coronavirus-little-if-any-possibility-hong-kong-schools|archive-date=22 March 2020|url-status=live}} The disruption raised concerns over the situation of students due to take examinations at the end of the year, especially in light of the protest-related disruption that happened in 2019.{{cite web |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3047662/china-coronavirus-hong-kong-students-face-exam-crunch |title=First protests, now virus: schools suspension could hurt those facing exams |first=Chris|last=Lau|date=26 January 2020 |website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=3 February 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200203063457/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3047662/china-coronavirus-hong-kong-students-face-exam-crunch |archive-date=3 February 2020 |url-status=live}} The [[Hong Kong Diploma of Secondary Education]] examination was postponed for four weeks from late March to late April, with [[HKEAA]] announcing that the oral component of both Chinese Language and English Language would be cancelled.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/4/144244/HKDSE-written-tests-to-be-delayed,-oral-exams-canceled|title=HKDSE written tests to be delayed, oral exams canceled|work=[[The Standard (Hong Kong)|The Standard]]|date=21 March 2020|accessdate=19 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200728232703/https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/4/144244/HKDSE-written-tests-to-be-delayed,-oral-exams-canceled|archive-date=28 July 2020|url-status=live}} On 5 February, flag carrier [[Cathay Pacific]] requested its 27,000 employees to voluntarily take three weeks of unpaid leave by the end of June. The airline had previously reduced flights to mainland China by 90% and overall flights by 30%.{{Cite news |last=Riley |first=Charles |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2020/02/05/business/cathay-pacific-coronavirus/index.html |title=Cathay Pacific asks workers to take 3 weeks off without pay as the coronavirus decimates travel |date=5 February 2020 |publisher=CNN |access-date=7 February 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200206100340/https://edition.cnn.com/2020/02/05/business/cathay-pacific-coronavirus/index.html |archive-date=6 February 2020 |url-status=live}} The arrest of dozens of pro-democracy activists and opposition politicians for protests organised and carried out during 2019 in the course of the [[2019–20 Hong Kong protests]], which included the arrest of 15 high-profile pro-democracy figures on 18 April,{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/18/world/asia/hong-kong-arrests.html|title=Amid Pandemic, Hong Kong Arrests Major Pro-Democracy Figures|first1=Elaine|last1=Yu|first2=Austin|last2=Ramzy|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 April 2020|access-date=1 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200418112007/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/18/world/asia/hong-kong-arrests.html|archive-date=18 April 2020|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url = https://hongkongfp.com/2020/04/18/8-hong-kong-pro-democracy-figures-arrested-in-latest-police-round-up-party-says/|title = 15 Hong Kong pro-democracy figures arrested in latest police round up|first = Rachel|last = Wong|newspaper = [[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date = 18 April 2020|access-date = 1 May 2020|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200422093046/https://hongkongfp.com/2020/04/18/8-hong-kong-pro-democracy-figures-arrested-in-latest-police-round-up-party-says/|archive-date = 22 April 2020|url-status = live}} was seen widely as having been expediated by the local restrictions on demonstrations, besides the decreased international attention due to the pandemic.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/18/world/asia/hong-kong-arrests.html|title=Amid Pandemic, Hong Kong Arrests Major Pro-Democracy Figures|first1=Elaine|last1=Yu|first2=Austin|last2=Ramzy|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 April 2020|access-date=28 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200418112007/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/18/world/asia/hong-kong-arrests.html|archive-date=18 April 2020|url-status=live}} Police have used coronavirus laws banning groups of more than four, for example, to disperse protesters outside Prince Edward station on 31 March,{{cite news |last1=Hui |first1=Mary |title=Hong Kong police are using coronavirus restrictions to clamp down on protesters |url=https://qz.com/1829892/hong-kong-police-use-coronavirus-rules-to-limit-protests/ |accessdate=19 April 2020 |work=Quartz |year=2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200418180835/https://qz.com/1829892/hong-kong-police-use-coronavirus-rules-to-limit-protests/ |archive-date=18 April 2020 |url-status=live }} and a 300-person singing protest in [[Cityplaza]] on 26 April.{{cite news |title=Hong Kong police break up pro-democracy singing protest at mall |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests/hong-kong-police-break-up-pro-democracy-singing-protest-at-mall-idUSKCN2280IK |accessdate=27 April 2020 |agency=Reuters |date=26 April 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200426221821/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests/hong-kong-police-break-up-pro-democracy-singing-protest-at-mall-idUSKCN2280IK |archive-date=26 April 2020 |url-status=live }} == Success factors at early stages == In a study published in April 2020 in the ''Lancet'', the authors expressed their belief that border restrictions, quarantine and isolation, social distancing, and behavioural changes such as wearing masks likely all played a part in the containment of the disease up to the end of March.{{cite news |url=https://ktla.com/news/coronavirus/infectious-disease-professor-in-hong-kong-ben-cowling-on-how-they-went-23-days-with-no-local-cases-of-covid-19/ |title=Infectious Disease Professor in Hong Kong, Ben Cowling on how they went 23 days with no local cases of COVID-19 |author=Pablo Chacon Jr. |date=14 May 2020 |publisher=[[KTLA]] |access-date=21 May 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200729020145/https://ktla.com/news/coronavirus/infectious-disease-professor-in-hong-kong-ben-cowling-on-how-they-went-23-days-with-no-local-cases-of-covid-19/ |archive-date=29 July 2020 |url-status=live }} Another important success factor is the critical thinking of citizens, who now distrust the government through lessons learned from the pro-democracy protests. ''The Atlantic'' credits the swift, collective and efficient grassroots movement. Already familiar with tides of misinformation during months of protests, obsessive fact-checking is practiced; after the 2003 SARS epidemic, claims about the non-transmissibility of the disease advanced by the government, the Communist Party and the WHO were also ignored by citizens, who took to wearing masks despite the anti-mask law in place.{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/dont-give-hong-kongs-government-the-credit/ar-BB13YFqh|work=The Atlantic|title=How Hong Kong Did It|first=Zeynep|last=Tufekci|date=12 May 2020|publisher=MSN|access-date=19 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200520110652/https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/dont-give-hong-kongs-government-the-credit/ar-BB13YFqh|archive-date=20 May 2020|url-status=live}} ==Criticism== === Policy comparisons with Macau === {{see also|COVID-19 pandemic in Macau}} The government actions with regards the epidemic in Hong Kong were inevitably compared with the "calm, organised handling" in neighbouring Macau, notwithstanding the relative sizes of the population. From the outset, [[COVID-19 pandemic in Macau|Macau demonstrated]] a faster and better coordinated response, introduced firm measures to limit the flow of people from mainland China, and implemented comprehensive collection and effective usage of big data.
