In particular, in contrast to long queues of desperate citizens chasing masks often at inflated prices in Hong Kong, Macau was lauded for providing their citizens with a measure of peace of mind by taking control of mask distribution, ensuring affordable masks were available for each Macau resident at the start of the epidemic.{{cite news|url=https://www.cna.com.tw/amp/news/firstnews/202003070209.aspx|script-title=zh:澳門走出武漢肺炎疫情 香港評論一致讚好|language=zh-t|agency=Central News Agency (Taiwan)|title=|access-date=19 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200320232406/https://www.cna.com.tw/amp/news/firstnews/202003070209.aspx|archive-date=20 March 2020|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3048494/macaus-calm-organised-handling-coronavirus-crisis-puts-hong-kong|first=Raquel|last=Carvalho|title=Macau's calm, organised handling of coronavirus crisis puts Hong Kong panic in perspective|website=[[South China Morning Post]]|access-date=19 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200518100412/https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3048494/macaus-calm-organised-handling-coronavirus-crisis-puts-hong-kong|archive-date=18 May 2020|url-status=live}} Immediately upon the detection of its first cross-border case, Macau closed its border with neighbouring Zhuhai. Macau's entry bans on Hubei residents, and those who had visited the province 14 days before their arrival in Macau, was similar to Hong Kong's ban on the surface, but the Macau authorities' demanding official medical certification of infection-free status brought down visitor numbers more sharply because such certificates are hard to obtain. The media reported that Macau police searched 86 hotels and deported about 150 visitors from Hubei and put 4 into voluntary quarantine, whereas immigration officers in Hong Kong checked 110 hotels, and only took down details of the 15 travellers identified as being from Hubei because none showed symptoms of Covid. While Macau Chief Executive [[Ho Iat-seng]] announced the measure, his Hong Kong counterpart was attending the [[World Economic Forum]] summit in Davos. === Border closure controversy === The Hong Kong Government refused to close all the borders with the mainland to reduce the risk of the virus entering Hong Kong, opting instead for progressive partial closures in response to increasing public pressure. There were calls for tightening up controls and checks for visitors, especially those coming from Wuhan, the point of origin of the epidemic.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3047660/china-coronavirus-hong-kong-leader-adopts-advice-medical|title=China coronavirus: Hong Kong leader adopts advice from medical experts – but draws line at closing border with mainland China|date=25 January 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=13 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200315175109/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3047660/china-coronavirus-hong-kong-leader-adopts-advice-medical|archive-date=15 March 2020|url-status=live}} Medical experts had demanded mandatory health declarations at all borders and ports but they were initially rejected. Chief Executive of Hong Kong [[Carrie Lam]] rejected proposals to close borders as "inappropriate and impractical", but said that mandatory declarations would be implemented. On 28 January, Lam announced that the high-speed rail link with mainland China, and all cross-border ferry services, would be suspended starting two days later. Additionally, the number of flights from mainland China and cross-border bus services were reduced. Hong Kong government employees (except those providing essential/emergency services) were asked to work from home. Later on that day, the government closed two border checkpoints. Government clarification that treatment for Coronavirus patients would be free for allcomers further inflamed Hong Kong residents as the policy ignited fears of infected mainland Chinese [[medical tourism|deliberately travelling]] to Hong Kong to seek medical care, thus risk spreading the disease as well as further overwhelming medical facilities. Following public uproar, the government re-imposed fees for non-Hong Kong residents.{{Cite web|url=https://hongkongfp.com/2020/02/01/explainer-7-reasons-hongkongers-angry-govt-response-coronavirus/|title=Explainer: 7 reasons Hongkongers are angry about the gov't response to the coronavirus|date=1 February 2020|website=Hong Kong Free Press|access-date=26 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200617201708/https://hongkongfp.com/2020/02/01/explainer-7-reasons-hongkongers-angry-govt-response-coronavirus/|archive-date=17 June 2020|url-status=live}} As the major border checkpoints such as [[Lo Wu Control Point|Lo Wu]], [[Lok Ma Chau Control Point|Lok Ma Chau]] and [[Huanggang Port|Huanggang]] remained open, public sector health workers, as represented by Hospital Authority Employees’ Alliance – a newly formed union – decried the government measures as "too little, too late".{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3047963/hong-kongs-partial-border-closure-amid-wuhan-coronavirus|title=Hong Kong's partial border closure amid Wuhan coronavirus crisis too little, too late, experts and health care workers' union say|date=29 January 2020|website=South China Morning Post}} Over 400 public hospital doctors and nurses also wrote to the government, demanding border closure and also threatening strike action.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3048457/coronavirus-thousands-public-hospital-staff-vote|title=Coronavirus: thousands of public hospital staff to vote on strike action on Saturday ahead of potential walkout next week|date=31 January 2020|website=South China Morning Post}} The union warned the government its members may go on strike in early February if the government failed to implement tighter controls on immigration. [[File:HKIA March 26, 2020 flights cancelled.jpg|thumb|Many flights from [[Hong Kong International Airport]] were cancelled in late March due to COVID-19]] ==== Strike call ==== Facing continued pressure from strikers and from all parties across the political divide, Lam announced a raft of measures including six further border closures on 30 January. Lam explained her government's insistence on keeping major border crossings open conformed with the WHO's position that draconian travel and trade restrictions were unnecessary, and it was opposed to any "discriminatory move" to close borders with China or restrict access to Chinese travellers.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3048419/hong-kong-leader-carrie-lam-urges-local-residents-not|title=Coronavirus: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam says total border shutdown with mainland China discriminatory, but will ramp up quarantine measures|date=31 January 2020|website=South China Morning Post}} On 3 February, the government closed all but four border crossings – the [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge]], [[Shenzhen Bay Port]], the [[Hong Kong International Airport|international airport]], and the [[Kai Tak Cruise Terminal]] – and introduced further quarantine measures, but still refused closing the border with China. After a union vote, a public hospital strikes ensued.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3049111/coronavirus-why-wont-carrie-lam-shut-hong-kongs-border|title=Why won't Carrie Lam shut Hong Kong's border with mainland China?|date=5 February 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=13 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200326042533/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3049111/coronavirus-why-wont-carrie-lam-shut-hong-kongs-border|archive-date=26 March 2020|url-status=live}} The strike involved 6,000 medical workers, lasted five days – from 3 to 7 February – culminating in an occupation of two floors in the Hospital Authority complex in Kowloon City. According to the authority, the industrial action had led to "severe disruption" to operations, particularly at accident and emergency, neonatal intensive care, cancer and cardiac units. A second strike call was not successful.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049512/hong-kong-medical-workers-strike-goes-level|title=Hong Kong medical workers vote down plans to extend strike into next week|date=7 February 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=18 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200530120954/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3049512/hong-kong-medical-workers-strike-goes-level|archive-date=30 May 2020|url-status=live}} Pundits noted that after the turmoil caused by her bungled handling of the extradition bill enactment, Carrie Lam lacked the political capital to make the demand for full border closure – something the Chinese government was not inclined to accede to. ===Quarantine loophole=== Neglected categories of arrivals in Hong Kong were said by experts to be responsible for imported COVID-19 infections between 8 and 21 July – 34 cases (30 per cent) were sea or aircrew members, and 28 (25 percent) were domestic helpers. In late June, the loophole was highlighted after nine ship workers who arrived with their vessel in Ningbo tested positive. The ship had made a three-day port call in Hong Kong on its way to Ningbo. Official figures show that more than 11,700 sea crew members have been exempted from quarantine since February, while Hong Kong still allows unrestricted sea crew change for vessels since 8 June. Prior to 8 July, sea and aircrew members were exempt from testing and quarantine. Since then, the authorities require sea and aircrew members to produce negative COVID-19 test results before coming to the city. However, a community outbreak is already under way. On 26 July, as the number of daily confirmed cases reached 128 – the second highest level since the start of the pandemic and the fifth consecutive day when cases numbered in excess of 100 and a death toll of 18 – the government announced that ships without any cargo trade sailing via Hong Kong would no longer be allowed to change their crew in the city from 29 July. Disembarking crew members would have to remain on the ship and wait to be transported to the airport to avoid community infections. Medical experts said that the government measures were "too little, too late", and further questioned why the measures were only applicable three days afterwards.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3094738/hong-kong-third-wave-sea-crew-changes-passenger|title=Experts question Hong Kong’s ‘late’ move to plug Covid-19 loopholes|date=26 July 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=27 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200727072102/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3094738/hong-kong-third-wave-sea-crew-changes-passenger|archive-date=27 July 2020|url-status=live}} According to experts, the acceleration of the community outbreak is due to the government's slow reactions and complacency of the public. Many Hongkongers believe the increase in cases is due to people who have entered the city from abroad without having been subjected to quarantine, and have appealed to the government to end the exemptions.''The New York Times'', 22 July 2020. "A model city's defenses felled by a virus surge" The government defended the loopholes for certain workers, such as cross-boundary truck drivers, sea and aircrew, as "essential to maintain the necessary operation of society and the economy". As the daily number of cases has hit three figures, government adviser Professor David Hui urged the government to suspend allowing the sea port for crew change; Dr Ho Pak-leung, microbiologist at the University of Hong Kong, said quarantine exemptions for sea crew members could be likened to a "doorless chicken coop".{{Cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3094653/hong-kong-third-wave-more-sailors-confirmed-covid|title=Hong Kong urged to suspend sea crew member Covid-19 quarantine exemptions|date=24 July 2020|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=25 July 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200725200318/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3094653/hong-kong-third-wave-more-sailors-confirmed-covid|archive-date=25 July 2020|url-status=live}} === Mass testing controversy === ==== Absence of public tender ==== The government embarked on a programme of mass testing, citing the need to limit the number of asymptomatic transmissions. Questions were raised about the absence of tendering procedures, and the contractors' credentials which critics deemed suspect. Carrie Lam said that there were only three companies that were capable of carrying out mass testing on the scale required; they were given exemptions under Hong Kong law by virtue of their being qualified in China. Arisina Ma, president of the Public Doctors' Association, decried the lack of transparency in inviting Chinese specialists and appointing Chinese companies to provide testing, saying that even senior health department officials were unable to give clear terms of reference of the interventions. Many local health experts questioned why the government chose a strategy of wasteful universal testing, instead of focusing testing on more people who are deemed to be in higher risk groups; others questioned why local laboratories were not solicited although they have spare capacity. Carrie Lam said that the Chinese government would absorb part of the cost. ==== Privacy concerns ==== Citizens were concerned about the privacy implications if the tests involved the subject's DNA. Since the first week of August, prior to the arrival of the mainland testing team, the city has been rife with rumours that the team was being sent to obtain DNA from residents through the tests and used for surveillance purposes.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/06/business/hong-kong-china-coronavirus-testing.html|title=China’s Offer to Help With Virus Testing Spooks Hong Kong|first1=Sui-Lee|last1=Wee|first2=Tiffany|last2=May|date=6 August 2020|work=The New York Times}} There is considerable public mistrust in the Hong Kong government which continues to fuel conspiracy theories.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/world/1961867/hong-kong-denies-mass-virus-tests-are-bid-to-harvest-dna|title=Hong Kong denies mass virus tests are bid to harvest DNA |website=Bangkok Post}}{{Cite web|url=https://hongkongfp.com/2020/08/09/weaponising-covid-19-how-state-suppression-breeds-distrust-and-disinformation-in-hong-kong/|title=Weaponising Covid-19: How state suppression breeds distrust and disinformation in Hong Kong|first=Shui-yin Sharon|last=Yam|date=9 August 2020|website=Hong Kong Free Press}} China's building of a DNA database and its use and biometric surveillance were of great concern to human rights activists, as was the fact that one of the contractors is on a US government blacklist for taking DNA for surveillance purposes. The government attempted to reassure the public that testing would be optional, and that tests carried out "would meet all legal requirements and that no samples would be sent back to the mainland". ==== Credibility of contractors ==== According to some press reports, the main business of China Inspection Company ({{zh|labels=no|t=中國檢驗有限公司}}), one of three contractors, was vehicle and electronic inspections, and had no track record whatsoever in medical testing. The board of its local subsidiary consisted of three people, none of whom was a qualified laboratory clinician and was thus not compliant with Supplementary Medical Professions Ordinance (Cap 359).{{Cite web|url=https://news.mingpao.com/pns/%e8%a6%81%e8%81%9e/article/20200804/s00001/1596478905016/%e7%8d%b2%e6%aa%a2%e6%b8%ac%e5%90%88%e7%b4%84-%e4%b8%ad%e6%aa%a2%e7%84%a1%e9%86%ab%e5%8b%99%e5%8c%96%e9%a9%97%e6%89%80%e8%aa%8d%e5%8f%af-%e8%b2%a0%e8%b2%ac%e6%8e%a8%e8%a1%8c%e5%ad%90%e5%85%ac%e5%8f%b8%e4%ba%a6%e7%84%a1-%e6%94%bf%e5%ba%9c-%e4%bc%99%e5%90%88%e6%a0%bc%e5%8c%96%e9%a9%97%e6%89%80%e6%8f%90%e4%be%9b%e6%9c%8d%e5%8b%99|script-title=zh:獲檢測合約 中檢無醫務化驗所認可 負責推行子公司亦無 政府：伙合格化驗所提供服務 |website=Ming Pao|language=zh}} A second contractor, [[BGI Group]] ({{zh|labels=no|t=華大基因|s=华大基因}}), one of the biggest companies conducting coronavirus testing in China, had a subsidiary blacklisted by the US government on allegations of taking DNA from [[Uyghurs]] in Xinjiang for surveillance purposes.{{Cite web|url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1541422-20200802.htm?|title=DNA won't be sent to mainland in virus testing: govt |publisher=RTHK}} === Health code scheme === {{Main |Hong Kong Health Code}} The health code scheme is a proposed pandemic preventive measure, featuring a mobile application that allows its users to prove their health statuses by showing a QR code. It was first suggested by Dr. Pak-Leung Ho in May 2020 and was later endorsed by the government on multiple occasions. The users of the health code scheme will be able to travel between [[Guangdong]], [[Hong Kong]], and [[Macau]] without going through the quarantine procedure, as they can simply present their health code which contains their [[nucleic acid test]] result.{{cite news |last1=李 |first1=恩慈 |title=新冠肺炎｜何栢良：三地有望放寬跨境　倡互認檢測結果時效訂7天 |url=https://www.hk01.com/%E7%A4%BE%E6%9C%83%E6%96%B0%E8%81%9E/472109/%E6%96%B0%E5%86%A0%E8%82%BA%E7%82%8E-%E4%BD%95%E6%A0%A2%E8%89%AF-%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%B0%E6%9C%89%E6%9C%9B%E6%94%BE%E5%AF%AC%E8%B7%A8%E5%A2%83-%E5%80%A1%E4%BA%92%E8%AA%8D%E6%AA%A2%E6%B8%AC%E7%B5%90%E6%9E%9C%E6%99%82%E6%95%88%E8%A8%827%E5%A4%A9 |accessdate=10 September 2020 |work=HK 01 |date=12 May 2020 |language=Chinese}}{{cite news |title=粵港澳正磋商特定者出入境豁免強制　何栢良：可用健康碼代替檢疫措施 |url=https://news.mingpao.com/ins/%E6%B8%AF%E8%81%9E/article/20200511/s00001/1589168883282/%E7%B2%B5%E6%B8%AF%E6%BE%B3%E6%AD%A3%E7%A3%8B%E5%95%86%E7%89%B9%E5%AE%9A%E8%80%85%E5%87%BA%E5%85%A5%E5%A2%83%E8%B1%81%E5%85%8D%E5%BC%B7%E5%88%B6-%E4%BD%95%E6%A0%A2%E8%89%AF-%E5%8F%AF%E7%94%A8%E5%81%A5%E5%BA%B7%E7%A2%BC%E4%BB%A3%E6%9B%BF%E6%AA%A2%E7%96%AB%E6%8E%AA%E6%96%BD |accessdate=10 September 2020 |work=Ming Pao |date=11 May 2020 |language=Chinese}} Moreover, there are suggestions from the [[Pro-Beijing camp (Hong Kong)|pro-establishment camp]] that all Hong Kong citizens should be required to install a health code app in order to enter public areas such as restaurants.{{cite news |title=香港全民检测成"港版健康码"？ 港人质疑变相全民监控 |url=https://www.rfa.org/mandarin/yataibaodao/gangtai/al-08132020074207.html |language=Chinese |accessdate=3 September 2020 |work=Radio Free Asia |date=13 August 2020}} Despite the support from multiple pro-establishment parties,{{cite news |title=建制團體聯合聲明　促推健康碼恢復中港經貿活動
